attributes.comment:
I am writing to argue against the current proposed fee increases as they relate to I-
600/I-600A petitions. Most adoptive parents will have to go through FBI
fingerprinting and USCIS I-600/I-600A approval at least twice for the adoption of
the same child due to the increasing length of the waiting times imposed by the
country from which they are adopting.

While the document expiration for the USCIS approval is a different issue from the
fee increase, they are interrelated. If the Congress and USCIS would change the
length that the documents are valid to accommodate the lengthening times for
most families to complete international adoption, then a small fee increase is not
as objectionable. As it is though, the proposed fee increase is almost 23% which
is higher than most businesses would increase their fees to cover costs in a
single year.

The frustrating part of having to resubmit the I-600/I-600 A forms is that generally
most families have little or no change to include in the resubmission. There are
additional forms that have to submitted which also need to be more current, thus
adding additional costs to the adoption process (birth certificates and marriage
license and an updated homestudy). If the length of time that these documents
are valid cannot be increased to accommodate the the actual time it takes to
adopt, then the fees for resubmission should be part of the original costs or a very
SMALL renewal fee should be charged. In most cases, families have to travel to a
USCIS Center which also requires time out of work and travel costs.

Again, I am opposed to an increased in these fees, especially given the fact that
the USCIS knows that most families are having to pay these fees TWICE as it is.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Sue
